title: Azir has too many Identities.
body: Currently Azir can be identified as a Zoning mage, Lane bully, Hyper carry, Poke mage, Siege mage, Wave clear mage, Tank shredder, Disengage mage, Sustained damage mage, And a Mage with burst. He Benefits way to much from {{item:3165}} and is pretty hard to catch due to his Dash, Ult, Soldier zoning and Long range. I don't know what could be done to make him less powerful but really shouldn't be this strong at so many things. I also think he shouldn't be able to chunk turrets with his W an Azir could go 25/3 or what ever type of score and completely destroy an enemies base. While defending his own without even using his W on the enemy turrets. So the fact that he has it is unneeded power if you ask me. Lets discuss about Azir and his current state because he is just too strong.

Ok so lets get one thing out of the way.  I was an Azir main all through s4, and I still play him in this season when there is a favorable match up.

His kit -IS- overloaded, but parts of it such as the turret passive are largely only useful in a niche situation.  The attack speed from CDR he absolutely needs because without it he wouldn't do any damage considering Nashors is literally the only item to grant both attack speed and AP for him.  The fact that he has some strengths in multiple areas doesn't make him OP because he also doesn't excel at any of those areas right now.  He's moderately good at all of them, but not actually doing better than any other champion.

Overall his win rate is sitting at 6th lowest in the game (under urgot).  Even between platinum and diamond level he resides around 44-45% winrate.  Azir sees play in LCS because those are premade teams who know their roles and work together everyday.  So, they can do things like plan to pick Nunu and Azir to combo out.  You can never do that in soloQ, and if you could there are plenty of other combo oriented champions (like yas and any knock up for example).

I just can't even believe anyone is still talking about nerfs for him.  He's been nothing but nerfed since release.  Azir was easily twice as strong on release than he is right now.  His range, damage, damage on his w to turrets and so on have all been nerfed more than once.

The biggest issue I see with Azir is a flat out misunderstanding of who he is as a champion and how he works.  For example, he doesn't actually shred tanks, it's just that many tanks don't build up as much innate MR and Azir has sustained damage.  So, for example, a Maokai will usually build rod of ages first, but is not likely to build any extra MR until later into the game.

His high skill cap and all that has nothing to do with his actual winrates or how much power he should have.  Rather he gets a little bit more power from his soldiers because of the level of micromanagement involved.  In other words instead of being an ADC and right clicking on your enemy Azir has to Q to said enemy line up his soldiers and start trying to auto them while keeping them in that circle.

I would upvote for this alone, but you made a lot of good points as well.

Azir's "poke" and "burst" is still oriented around his management of his soldiers, which is also the source of his sustained damage. I just don't see any necessary nerfs to be made, even if we all agreed his poke and burst needed to be nerfed. The vast majority of his damage are already on his soldiers; I suppose Q has decent damage too, but not nearly as much as pretty much any burst-y mage you can think of. Azir has no "rotation" so while Q might hurt, it's not like an Ahri Q or a Leblanc....anything. They have a rotation to follow up on that initial damage. Azir does not have that, he relies on enemies remaining in the range of his soldiers (through various means--ally CC, Q movement, etc) for a long while, to deal damage over time. And that's exactly the definition of sustained damage. 

Plus he's got a pretty high skill cap so it's hard for me to say any nerfs are justified; most nerfs would just punish skill players, it's not like he's freelo for people who don't play him.

I have to concede that Azir is far from freelo.  If you take a look on champion.gg, even players who are Plat+ still have a low winrate in ranked games with Azir, until they play about 50 or more.  At that point its slightly above average (which would be expected for any champion that somebody plays consistently and repeatedly).  

Also, your main statement here gave me a lot to reflect on.  I never really thought that over; "Azir does not have a rotation.".  I still firmly believe his poke is a bit too strong, but that leaves me a lot to think about in why I enjoy Azir.

He has 0 burst without items and it is usually a bad idea to run ignite on him. Which means that you can duel someone, come out on top, but have to capability to force that person to stay in lane other than threatening their tower.

I love Azir. When he was released I was so sad because he was so amazing but was held back by glaringly HUGE bugs. Now that some of the bugs are gone, he has been nerfed suuuuper hard because he can be quite punishing to players for making mistakes.

Now he is barely at 50% his normal strength, has an incredibly low winrate, and is needing advertisement on the homepage as an effort from Riot to say "look! Azir is totally viable!" just like they did with Viktor not too long ago to try to spike his pick rate.

His low win rate is the result of his rather large play rate.  There are too many people that are inexperienced on him bringing it down.  He's still very capable and I find myself running ignite most often unless I am in draft pick / ranked and I know I am against a burst heavy matchup (Talon, Zed, LeBlanc, etc).

He really isn't too big of a bully until he gets the components to Morellonomicon, that is when he actually starts to have strong harass potential.

I would argue that asking for nerfs in this way isn't always a call to weaken a champ, but to trim unneeded/toxic stuff off their kit to make room for power that is more useful/enjoyable. The Veigar rework was kind of an example of this, as they tried to nerf his stun in order to reduce the toxicity of his kit and allow him to be more powerful in other areas (his Q).

As somebody who mains Azir (and has since the end of April) I think I have a good idea as to what Azir's identity should be, what it is right now, and what changes would need to be made to accommodate it.  

Azir right now has a lot of things he can do.  His Q and W allow him to poke somebody substantially, his E gives him some mobility (which can become very high mobility if used correctly), and his R can completely change the landscape of a fight.  His passive is simply an AA steroid (one that is made to work with Azir's itemization) plus the turret active (which is cool af).  Right now if played correctly (which fortunately takes a fairly decent amount of time to learn how) he can respond to just about every situation.

Azir intended niche is a mage who specializes in control, sustained magic damage, and safety.  I would define safety as strong waveclear, decent (but properly gated) mobility, and a CC that gives you a chance at redemption from a bad situation.  The very nature of his kit gives him lane bullying because of his W, but that spell is so integral to Azir that it probably cannot be modified much if at all.   Azir should be strong at killing tanks much like an ADC, and through his Ult and placement/movement of his soldiers he can control the pace of a fight and how it plays out if the player is adept at Azir.  What Azir shouldn't be doing is taking most of a champion's HP with just a Q -> AA once he has a Deathcap.

The solution to this?  Well, Azir has a lot of multipliers throughout his kit.  Sustained damage generally scales through these multipliers.  For Azir, these multipliers are attack speed, CDR, AP, and magic penetration.  Additionally, striking enemy champions with more than one soldier with Q or an auto-attack makes the second strike deal reduced damage (but still acts as a damage multiplier).  

A good solution (without being too drastic) could be reducing the AP ratio of his Q further (maybe down to 30%?), lowering the AP Ratio on his W (down to 50%), and then increasing his base attack speed from .625 to something more commonly found on an ADC (.658 is common).  If needed, they could also increase the attack speed he receives from his passive.  This would encourage item builds, runes, and masteries to include some source of bonus attack speed outside of his passive.  You can still easily achieve high levels of AP without a Luden's Echo and the AP item changes on PBE will also be a catalyst for this.  

Personally, I never build Luden's on him (unless stupidly fed).  I prefer to purchase a Stinger after building Morellonomicon -> T2 Boots -> Deathcap.  I then proceed with a normal build until my final item (where I would finish Stinger into Nashor's Tooth).  I generally end up with 1.5-ish attack speed, 720 AP or more, and 40% CDR (over-capped by 5% because of masteries).  I may not be able to poke as hard (keep in mind, your poke is still EXTREMELY potent), but in teamfights I'm feared by tanks and squishies alike.  It also just feels more natural, more how I feel Azir should play (and thus became my preference).

Also, they could remove the tower-damaging active from Azir's W if they wanted.  It feels like unnecessary power in my opinion, and doesn't really contribute too much to Azir's theme.

I can agree that at times Azir's E may feel a bit over the top for the fact that Azir's wall is already impassable (barring Fizz E and Vlad W, as well as the few blinks in this game).  He honestly does have a lot of fallback plans if something goes haywire.  And also, perhaps that idea for a short delay as to when the soldier(s) can attack after moving his Q could work.  I feel as though it could feel a bit wonky at times, but we'd have to see first.

There's honestly a lot of power that could be shaved from Azir and then dispersed throughout his kit in more fitting ways, its just identifying everything.  A few things such as his W being able to damage towers for magic damage (when targeting an enemy tower), or his Ult knocking you back if you dash into it after it has been placed (like, if the initial cast is already over and an enemy dash into the wall as it stands still they will be knocked back again).

If any balance changes toward Azir were to be focused on changing his damage, I'd strongly encourage they focus on making him the premier DPS mage (second only to Cassiopeia, who is supposed to be a poison mage.  Poor Cass players).

>or his Ult knocking you back if you dash into it after it has been placed (like, if the initial cast is already over and an enemy dash into the wall as it stands still they will be knocked back again).

This is actually a technical limitation, not a balance one. The point it to make it impassible by all *possible* means. If they use a standard wall, people will simply dash through it (see Anivia).
 If they use a stun or a root (see Vieger), the people would have to be allowed through after the CC or become permanently CC'ed. The knock-back prevents them from getting through *and* removes them from the "CC Zone". They're aren't really any other options to achieve the intended goal with LoL's current technology.

That would explain this behavior.  At least the wall isn't coded as minions, right?

I used to attempt that too when I first started learning Azir.  The problem is that it delays CDR on him and requires time to ramp up.  With Morellonomicon or Athene's you get the instant AP, CDR, and mana regen which allows you to pursue pure damage on your next item (often a Rabadon's Deathcap).  Otherwise, that build would be perfect for Azir.

Azir's kit is overloaded, and he is really overwhelming right now in the hands of a player that plays him even reasonably well. He needs targeted nerfs that emphasize some sort of strength while creating some clearer weakness.
Azir's power is balanced out by his difficulty. And a major part of his strength is from a lack of experience playing against him.

Thing is, a high skill cap shouldn't justify straight up having more options available than other champions.  Take a look at Lee Sin throughout Season 3 and 4.  He was constantly played in pro play because they could play him to his maximum potential (or damn near).  This champion was among the safest picks because of his mobility, durability, early damage, and fallback plan late-game (his R).  We're seeing the same situation with Azir right now (though instead with a weaker early game and very strong late-game, but he still starts to get bonkers once he gets just a Codex and Forbidden Idol).

And now Lee Sin has been played significantly less because he can't do everything like people thought he could. The tank meta rolled in and proved that Lee Sin wasn't as good a tank as Sejuani or Gragas. So they use him less in the pro scene.

This occurred because of the introduction of Cinderhulk.  If not for the advent of that (leading to the rise of tank junglers, and subsequent nerfs) he'd still be played just as much.  Still, Sejuani was very strong before Cinderhulk.

You are absolutely right. My main point here is that at the time Lee was huge, people thought he could do everything. Yet along comes a change--not a direct nerf to Lee--and Lee can't keep up as well. Thus, he had a weakness at the time, the right change had to come along and make it significant. They didn't need to nerf Lee into the ground or anything like that.

You are most likely a better player than me, but I don't see any azir matches in your history.  Have you tried playing him and learning his strengths and weaknesses?  The best counter for any character is knowing how to play them, and against them.

I'm still a newb, but the characters I have the easiest time winning against are the ones I play regularly.  If I get stomped by a character, I add them to my list of characters to try, so I can understand them better and maybe beat them in the future.

Like with Azir, if he spawns two soldiers, chances are you should go in once the first one vanishes.  He can summon at most 1 more while you are fighting him, and he will probably have to use it to escape, and it will burn some mana.  Or, if he throws his soldiers at you with Q, get between him and the soldiers before he uses E.  He will do some damage and get a shield, but if you have him outside of his soldiers aa range and his E is down, you can probably solo him.

You could also try characters that have long range poke.  I bet he'd have a heck of a time against a lux, ezreal, velkoz, or kogmaw.  I wouldn't want to be a melee champ against an experienced azir tho.  I got my butt kicked by yasuo in my 2nd game with azir, but I can see how he would typically destroy in the scenario.

Eh, since his last round of nerfs, Azir is on a weak spot, tbh. He has interesting niches in competitive play but that's it, try playing him yourself one day to see his obvious weaknesses, such as his window of weakness right after he uses w+q to poke.
